por.por_cntn:
The energy demand of the industrialized world is currently supplied predominantly (~78%) by fossil fuels. It is estimated that this proportion will remain virtually unchanged for at least the next 30–40 years, bolstered further by the recent expansion of economically exploitable natural gas reserves. While the latter constitutes a unique opportunity for the domestic industry, continued fossil-fuel utilization will aggravate the increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration, which has already reached historically unprecedented levels. In parallel, the rapidly increasing world population and continuous improvements in living standards are causing an increasing demand for consumer products and hence for the raw materials used to make them, many of which are produced by chemical processes from fossil fuels (oil or natural gas). These drivers are motivating the development of new processes that combine carbon capture (for low-carbon power generation) with the utilization of fossil resources to produce value added products with a reduced anthropogenic carbon footprint.

In this context, “chemical looping” has recently emerged as a clean combustion technology. Chemical looping utilizes a so-called oxygen carrier, typically a metal oxide, to combust the fuel in a “reducer reactor” at high temperatures. The resultant product stream, composed mainly of CO2 and H2O, allows the separation of CO2 through simple condensation of water to yield sequestration-ready CO2 streams. The reduced oxygen carrier is then re-oxidized with air in an “oxidizer reactor” and recycled back to the reducer reactor. Thus, chemical looping combustion (CLC) offers an elegant and efficient path towards carbon capture with minimal energy penalty by splitting conventional combustion into two separated sub-reactions.

The present project demonstrated the extension of chemical looping from an elegant combustion technology with inherent carbon capture towards the use as a partial oxidation process for efficient production of synthesis gas, the key intermediate in the production of value-added products from natural gas. We demonstrated that replacing air with CO2 as results in a novel, intensified route for CO2 activation via reduction to CO (via the chemical looping analogue of dry reforming).  Furthermore, by controlling process conditions (and hence the degree of carrier oxidation), the oxidation of the fuel (methane) can be steered selectively towards production of synthesis gas. Suitable process configurations hence enable the direct production of synthesis gas with the adjustable composition for various typical downstream processes, combining high flexibility and superior efficiency with an economically viable and locally available resource (natural gas).

Overall, our results demonstrate the utility of ‘chemical looping’ as a highly flexible platform for efficient and safe, next-generation fuel conversion technologies, and a key concept for the development of so-called “intensified processes” in the chemical industry.
